div.p: 1. V:45. Tuesday

Cooler weather, and some appearance of rain all day. I worked, an hour or more in my garden, and was interrupted by the visit of Mr and Mrs Gales of Washington, with their adopted daughter, Miss Walker. My wife and Mary had gone into Boston, to see Charles’s wife and baby, but they returned home to dine. The Lessons to my Granddaughter try my philosophy— I read the report of the Committee of Common the Council of the Commonwealth, upon the judgement of judge Peter Thacher of the Municipal Court in Boston upon an Indictment against the Mayor and Aldermen of the City for a false return of the Election for a member of Congress from the District on the first Monday of April last. They omitted from the return 332 votes, given for George Odiorne, the Anti-masonic candidate— Some days after they made a second return which the Council refused to receive— The judge decided that the Governor and Council ought to have received the second return— The Antimasons petitioned the Governor and Council to take the opinion of the judges of the Supreme Court, which they refuse, because they entertain no doubt that the decision of the judge was wrong, Such is the Administration of Justice, when Masonry and Anti-masonry are at issue. The judge pronounces the Council wrong— The Council pronounce the judge wrong; and the Antimasons suffer by both decisions. I read also the second Canto of Zophiel, and wrote to my Son Charles about Insurance at the Mutual Office— Lost a rubber and game at whist.
2. IV:45. Wednesday.

Rainy night and morning. Changes of wind, from North-east to South-west; and then to North-west— Showery day and cleared off at night. Finished my Letter to Richard Rush, and wrote one to Coll. Josiah Quincy junr. He came immediately and expressed great mortification at the inferences drawn from his Letter in the Daily Advertiser of last Monday, concerning the publication of my Letter to John Brazier Davis of 6. April 1832 in the same paper two days before.— He said Davis’s father, and two brothers had been in prodigious excitement at the publication of this Letter, one of the brothers having just returned from India—why they were excited he did not state; but it was the crafty frenzy of Masonry— The pure Spirit which sunk Morgan in the waters of the Niagara— They insisted upon Quincy’s writing and publishing the Letter which he did, and urged him to make it stronger— He suffered himself to be made their tool, and after I had told him that the Letter was mine, and had been published with my assent, he published this declaration that he was the administrator of Mr Davis, and that he had never seen this Letter—the effect of which was to make a question of its authenticity, and accordingly the Newspapers opposed to my election charge me with forging my own Letter— And all this because Alexander H. Everett in publishing the Letter, foolishly stated that the Letter was found among Davis’s papers after his death— Mr Quincy was so much mortified and in so much terror of getting into difficulty himself that my resentment at his publication subsided into compassion— He professed a disposition to do any thing in his power to repair the injury he had done me— I desired him to communicate my Letter to him, to Mr Davis’s family and to assure them that asserting my own right to publish my own Letter at my pleasure, I would not have consented to its publication, if I had been aware that they had the slightest objection to it. And then I should leave him to take such measures as he himself should think proper, to remove the effect
of the inferences drawn by the Boston Courier, dishonourable to me, from his Statement. Both of which he promised to do.— I read the third Canto of Zophiel— The Poem is a singular mixture of the story of Tobit, of the Heathen Mythology, and of the Rosicrusian demonology.
3. V. Thursday.

Again a clear sky and a fine day— My Son John went to Boston, and Charles came back with him to dinner. Mary went with my wife after dinner, and paid a number of visits to take leave— I read parts of several pamphlets— At 6 O’Clock this Evening, my Son John, with his wife, his second daughter, Georgiana Frances, her Nurse Mrs Goode, and the Mulatto boy Alfred Thomas left us to return to Washington— Gillet with the Quincy Stage, and a pair of horses, took them to Dedham where they are to pass the Night and await the Stage from Boston to Providence to-morrow Morning and they proceed by Stage, Steamer and Railway as fast as they can go, to Washington. This was to me, a melancholy parting. A strong presentiment weighs upon my mind that this is the last visit he will make to Quincy with his family; and that he goes to a destiny towards which I cannot look with composure— We are all in the hands of a merciful God: but human life wears away, all must, and by the general Law of moral as well as physical nature, that which has flourished must have its time for decay: and when that has once begun, nothing can arrest its course—it must perish— Such is the lot to which I myself am verging and which seems to extend with irreversible proclivity to my family— My Son John had devoted himself with the most unbounded filial affection and duty to my fallen Fortunes— He has been my kindest friend—my Steward, my Housekeeper, my Secretary, and my social companion— I had provided for him by the purchase of the Columbian Mills, a reputable, and I had a reasonable hope, would prove a profitable occupation— He gave to it the most assiduous and intelligent industry— It has failed by no fault or neglect of his, and has involved him and me heavily in debt. The disappointment preys like a gangrene upon his Spirits— It is now a year and a half since he was attacked with a disease in his eyes, which almost deprived him of sight— In July of last year he came with me from Washington to Philadelphia to consult Dr Physick upon that complaint, but Dr Physick was absent from Philadelphia, and he did not see him— He consulted Dr Hopkinson however, who made light of it, and John returned without relief to Washington.— I parted from him then as now, with an evil-boding mind, and an almost breaking heart— He has within these few weeks partially recovered his sight—may he wholly recover his sangwine Spirit and his active Industry, and obtain a blessing upon it—a more honest Soul, or more tender heart never breathed on the face of this Earth— O, if agonizing prayer could prevail! but may my Soul be prepared for whatever may befall. John Kirke went with them to Dedham, and returned about 10 at Night. I read the 4th. Canto of Zophiel. The Convention of National Republicans at Worcester unanimously nominated John Davis as their Candidate for Governor.
4. V:15. Friday.

The Night was much disturbed, and I had little Sleep— Silent Sorrows are the deepest, and mine must be inflexibly suppressed. Mrs Eustis and her niece Miss Harris paid Mrs Adams a morning visit. I planted a few Seeds and Stones of fruits in the garden, but was as usual interrupted in my labour. I visited also the ground sown with Solomon Thayer’s grain, which is coming up thick in some places but very much scattered.
My Son Charles came out from Boston— Mr Edward Everett had been to him, to suggest to him for my consideration the expediency of my withdrawing my name as a Candidate for the Office of Governor of the State in favour of John Davis— To this step Everett had been urged by George Bancroft, Davis’s brother in Law, who after the unanimous nomination stipulated for by Davis, as the condition of his acceptance, came post haste to charge Edward Everett to negotiate with me to withdraw, in favour of Davis my name from the nomination— I had told Alexander H. Everett, that if the Convention at Worcester would nominate his brother Edward, or any man, whom the Antimasons would support, I would cheerfully withdraw my name, and Edward supposes that if I would withdraw now, a part of the Antimasons would support Davis— I desired Charles to say to Edward Everett that I had the same disposition to do any thing in my power that was honest to restore Union and harmony to the National Republican party, and that I wished him to make his proposition to me in writing. Charles said he was confident Everett would not write. I desired him to say to him in that case, that if he would come and see me I would converse with him on the subject— He will probably not do this, for on reflection he will be ashamed of the project he has undertaken, and will say no more about it— Charles said Coll. Quincy had been to him about the matter of my Letter to John B. Davis, and would write to him a Letter, stating the facts that he might publish.
5. IV:45 Saturday.

My wife went into Boston this morning, and took with her Charles’s child Louisa, with her Nurse Mrs Field, who was homesick. The child is better than when she came out. My wife returned home to dine. I planted a row of Nursery crab apples, between the Elms and Oaks at the North end of the Nursery, and a row of dwarf Apples, with Pear Cores, Peach and Plum Stones between two Peach trees in the Garden. Alexander H. Everett was here; and gave me some account of the proceedings at the Worcester Convention of National Republicans— A nominating Committee of two members from each Congressional District was appointed, excepting Shaw’s district from which there was but one member at the Convention— This Committee were about five hours out, and could not make a majority for any one Candidate— They finally reported the names of N. Silsbee and William B. Calhoun— A young man from Boston named Park, moved to add the name of John Davis, and spoke slightingly of the two men, whose names were returned— Mr Grennell who had been a member of the nominating Committee said Mr Davis had declared that he would not accept the nomination on account of ill health, and other reasons— His name was nevertheless added— A committee was then appointed to enquire if he would accept, and they reported that he would, and he was then nominated unanimously, by acclamation— Everett said that finding it would be impossible to carry in the Convention a nomination of me, he had intended not to attend the Convention; but that two or three days before the Meeting, several of the party in Boston had thought the Worcester Convention might nominate his brother Edward— That Davis himself had been in his favour; but that it was impossible to get up a nomination of him in the Convention. Alexander said he had declined being on the State Committee of which he has been two or three years the Chairman, and William Sullivan is appointed in his place— He said he had gone to Worcester, in company with William Sullivan, and had found
him exceedingly prejudiced against me— That he was generally much influenced by Mr Webster, and he had told him that Webster was for confirming the nomination of the Antimasonic convention— But it had no effect upon him— Sullivan has the double venom of Hartford Convention federalism and of spurious Masonry in his blood. I told Everett that Sullivan was one of Otis’s compurgators, in their attack upon me in 1829. and that he had been confronted with a book of his own, upon Morals, in a debate in the Legislature, when it was proved that the Masons had bought him with his Land— It was a curiosity that the Worcester Convention appointed a Committee of which Everett himself is Chairman, to write the Address to the People in support of the nomination— I said to him that I had one request to make with respect to that—which was that he would be sparing of my name in it. He said that he had not yet begun the writing of it— That he had intended to say something respectful and complimentary of me, in it. I desired him to take no notice of me at all— The Convention had taken none, though he knew that the whole of their proceedings were impelled by the single motive of excluding me; and that any token of respect in their name to me would be too gross a mockery— They had treated me, much as the Legislature of New-York had treated DeWitt Clinton when they turned him out from being a Canal Commissioners. Everett said that he had acted with the National Republican party, upon public principle; but he thought he should decline a re-election to the Senate of the State. The masonic faction was so strong it was impossible to resist them; and if he should decline he thought he should leave the State— He spoke also about his publication of my Letter to John Brazier Davis; upon which I said Coll. Quincy was to write something to be published, after which he would hear from me again
6. V:30. Sunday

Heard Mr Whitney this Morning from 1. Corinthians 11.24—“This do in remembrance of me”—a Communion Sermon, and the Communion was administered after it. In the afternoon he preached from Hebrews 4.2. “For unto us was the gospel preached as well as unto them: but the word preached did not profit them, not being mixed with faith in them that heard it”— Mr Whitney gave notice that from this time forth during the ensuing Winter, the services would begin at half past ten in the morning; and at a quarter before two in the afternoon.— I read the Sermon of Saurin upon the Song of Simeon, for Christmas day—being the second of the 5th. Volume— It is eloquent, but not equal to the magnitude of the subject— There is too much of it upon the character of Simeon; concerning whom nothing is known, but what appears on the occasion of his Song— I read little else, being occupied much of the day in writing— Coll. Quincy was here this Evening and shewed me a paragraph or Letter that he had prepared to send to the Editor of the Daily Advertiser concerning my Letter to John B. Davis, which Mr Quincy’s former Statement the Masonic Papers, had taken the occasion to question whether it had ever been written by me at the date which it bears— Quincy now states that he had seen the original Letter, and some circumstances relating to the sale of it after Davis’s death—but repeats that neither he, nor Davis’s family knew of its existence— I desired him to add that he had also seen Davis’s Letter to me to which mine was an answer; and that he would enquire of Governor Lincoln, if he had not received from me a Letter of the same date, recommending Davis for the appointment. He said he would write to Governor Lincoln concerning it to-morrow.
7. V:15. Monday

The state of my health, I fear is irretrievable— The Summer is gone, and I have done nothing of what I had intended. My time is now absorbed 1. In the morning minutes of Thomson’s translation of the Septuagint Bible. 2. In teaching my grand-child Mary-Louisa to read—a task to which I devote from two to three hours of every day. 3. In the exercise of my garden and Nursery. An average of two hours more 4. My Diary one hour. 5. Correspondence two hours. 6 Miscellaneous reading two hours— There are twelves—Seven in bed— Three at and after Meals—and two wasted I know not how— This wasted time, I have found by constant experience to be as indispensable as Sleep— It cannot be employed in reading, nor even in thinking upon any serious subject— It must be wasted upon trifles; doing nothing— The string of the bow much be slackened, and the bow itself lain aside— Two hours a day is hardly sufficient allowance for this self-involution into a Chrysalis— I executed this day an Indenture of Lease of the Boylston House in School Street for one year, renewable for ten at 1000 dollars yearly rent, payable quarterly, and answered a Letter from Elbridge G. Howe. My Son Charles came out from Boston and dined with us, and returned this Evening. He had some additional anecdotes, respecting the nomination of John Davis at the Worcester Convention— He says that Davis was finally prevailed upon to accept the nomination, by an urgent Letter from Governor Lincoln— I desired Charles to suggest to the Anti Masonics in the event of a failure of election of Governor by the People, when the selection of the two Candidates comes to be made by the House of Representatives, to drop me altogether, so as to have their whole strength to give to two out of three Candidates instead of four. I began the answer of a Letter from George A. Otis.
8. V:45. Tuesday.

Showery day, and heavy rain at Night. I was all the morning confined to my chamber, hearing my Granddaughter read, and reading and writing myself. I finished my Letter to George A. Otis, upon his translation of Cicero’s Offices, and sent it to Charles at Boston. Wrote another short Letter— Visited my Garden and Nursery after dinner— The ground and Plants are falling into the decays of Autumn, and their Appearance is no longer inviting as in Summer. I planted two Canada Plum Stones, in Pot N. 12, and sundry Seeds and Stones in one of the places where I had last year set out my young budded Pear trees, which have been killed by the fireblight. I went towards Evening to Mrs T. B. Adams’s, and delivered to her a Letter from her Son Joseph, the Midshipman now in the Mediterranean, dated in July last at Trieste. I was caught in a shower of rain going, and was quite drenched in returning— Elizabeth C. Adams said if her aunt should go to Boston to-morrow, she would wish to go with her— I read an old Sermon of my sometime kinsman Zabdiel Adams of Lunenburg; delivered at Lexington, the 19th. of April 1783. It seems a religious Anniversary was observed there, during the whole Revolutionary War. This discourse was delivered, between the preliminary Articles of Peace of 30. Novr. 1782 and the definitive Treaty of 3. September 1783— I also began writing a draught of a Paper which will keep me occupied too long, and which I am afraid will lead me, I know not where— Mary Louisa planted a Walnut.
9. V. Wednesday.

The night continued showery, and there was rain this Morning, but it afterwards cleared off. My wife went to Boston, and took Elizabeth C. Adams, and our Grandchild Mary-Louisa with her. They returned to dine, and after dinner my wife took Elizabeth home— She paid also a farewell visit to Mrs Coll. Quincy— They are going to-morrow to Boston for the Winter. Governor Lincoln in answer to Coll. Quincy’s enquiry whether he had received in April 1832 a Letter from me recommending Coll. John Brazier Davis for the appointment of County Attorney for the County of Suffolk, informs him that he can say nothing of any communication which he has received from me without my permission— A shuffling pretext to evade an honest answer to my question, and a specimen of Levi Lincoln’s electioneering morals; giving an insight clear enough into his character— Yet this man has been nine years a popular Governor of the Commonwealth. Alpheus Spear sent me his Son, with his rent for the last Quarter; but it was not correctly counted, and I sent it back, desiring the boy to tell his father, that I wished to speak to him— I planted a Wollaston Apple, Peach and Plum Stones, and Apple and Pear Seeds in one of the Stands of the Garden— Towards Evening I took a walk round Mr Daniel Greenleaf’s Pasture, and wharf— Found one solitary black Oak Acorn, which I planted in the garden near Mary-Louisa’s Walnut— I wrote in the Evening a short Letter to Governor Lincoln, and continued writing a Narrative, which may lead me into troublesome controversy. A paper to be addressed to the People of the Commonwealth, and to be published at some future time— It is embracing already topics of the deepest interest and extremest delicacy— Perhaps it would be better for me to retire in Silence from all public affairs forever.
10. IV:15. Thursday

I continue my plantations, and this morning planted a row of Dwarf Apples, Pear Cores, Peach and Plum Stones, and Garden Walnuts in the drupe, between two young Peach trees in the Garden, and a row of Apple seeds in the patch, at the West end of the Garden— Mr Bailey was here this forenoon— He wished for a minute of the principal public measures of Mr Monroe’s administration, in which I had the chief Agency; and also of the leading measures of my own administration as President of the United States— But in preparing such minutes I have an invincible repugnancy to taking any part whatever— I cannot reconcile myself to writing for the promotion of my own election—not even by the refutation of the basest calumnies. In all my election contests therefore, my character is at the mercy of every Slanderer; and Slander is so effective a weapon in all our elections, that the Candidates for the highest Offices, use it without scruple against each other. It never was more atrociously used than it is at this moment against me— Mr Bailey mentioned that the State Committee of the Anti-Masons had it in contemplation, and were very desirous of nominating John Welles, as their Candidate for the Office of Lieutenant Governor, which I fully approved, though very sure that he will not accept the nomination. Mr Bailey has hopes that there will be a choice of Governor by the People, or at least that the largest vote will be for me. But I know by experience too well the power of Party Spirit upon the People, and the concentrated malignity of three great parties in the Commonwealth personally against me— There is no instance in the History of this State of a party nomination controuled by the votes of the People— Party triumphs over party; but the People are all enrolled in one party or another— The People can act only by the machinery of party.
Alpheus Spear was here this afternoon; and will consider whether he will pay the Parish tax for the Mount Wollaston farm or not. Postponed the payment of his Rent— My wife went and took tea at Mrs T. B. Adams’s. I walked over the hills, and gathered some pignuts, and black Oak Acorns. Continued my manuscript Speculation.
11. IV:30. Friday

O Time! Time! how impossible it is to predetermine, in what manner thou shalt be employed! Last Evening my wife went and took tea, at Mrs T. B. Adams’s— I was at home alone, and after giving a lesson of reading to my Granddaughter, I spent the remainder of it in writing— As I write my subject expands before me, till I become bewildered, with it, and find myself like a mariner who should embark upon an excursion for pleasure, and should Sail till he lost sight of Land, and should then discover that he had neither chart nor compass onboard— The waters deepen as I go; and the bottom is already beyond the reach of my line. William Spear was here this morning, and proposed to advertise the sale of the wood remaining on the Borland lot, for the 1st. of November, to which I assented—intending to leave this place for Washington, the last day of this Month. His brother Daniel, the Deacon, is still confined, chiefly to his house, and will probably never be an active man again— After dinner I rode with my wife to Roxbury, to return the visits, of Mrs Eustis and Miss Harris. They were gone to Cambridge— The visit of Mrs Eustis to us, was kindly intended; and there was a delicacy of feeling in the time which she selected for it, that we shall not forget.— My writing of last Evening gave me the Nightmare in bed this morning; so that I was compelled to renounce writing at Night, and I began reading Professor Dew’s Review of the debate in the Legislature of Virginia, upon the proposal for the abolition of Slavery. The author sent me this pamphlet, and I have long intended to read it. I found in its pages now some important information, and some curious argument. I planted sundry Walnuts, Apples and Apple-seeds, Pear Cores, and Peach and Plum-stones in the Garden.
12. V:15. Saturday.

Second nearly sleepless Night— My wife went into Boston, and took our Granddaughter Mary-Louisa with her— They returned home to dine. I planted sundry rows of Apples, and Apple-seeds, with garden Walnuts, Plum, Peach and cherry-stones— In a single spot of many which I planted, a strawberry vine has come up— Planted one row of whole dwarf Apples— The frost has killed the grape-leaves of all my seedling vines. Six foreign in one spot—and four native scattered. A Mr Holbrook of Fairlee, Vermont, a traveller called to see my by way of curiosity— He enquired if Edward Livingston had answered my Anti-masonic Letters— I said he had not— I gave him a copy of each of the two publications. The Letters on the entered Apprentice’s Oath, and those to Livingston— Mr Holbrook spoke of Mrs Niles, mother of a late Secretary of Legation to France, and said she was a Sister of judge John Davis’s deceased wife— Immediately after dinner Alexander Townsend came, and spent the Evening with me till near 8 O’Clock in multifarious conversation upon Politics and Literature. He said he would give me one day’s notice when he would come out, with Mr and Mrs Hunnewell— Townsend has
talents, Literature, good and enthusiastic feeling, but lacks discretion— He told me that Mr Lord had desired him to mention to me that he had received an order for one thousand copies of Dermot M’Morrogh from the State of Ohio— It must be from the same Source as the application last Winter from the Western part of New-York— A glimpse of fair sky in the Storm— The fortunes of this poem may teach me a lesson of self-knowledge, perhaps too late in Life to be available for my own benefit.
13. V. Sunday—

Another sleepless, but not wholly cheerless night— Heard a young man from Roxbury, by the name of Robbins, in the morning from John 6.12. [“]Gather up the fragments that remain, that nothing be lost” and in the afternoon from John 7.49—[“]But this People, who knoweth (know) not the Law are cursed.” The discourses were sensible: that of the morning especially—but the delivery was sluggish and drawling— The auditory was very thin—the day being tempestuous and showery— There was rain almost all night— I read the third Sermon of the 5th. Volume of Saurin—upon the last Discourses of Jesus Christ to his Apostles— For the first Sunday of Lent; or of what he calls the Passion Weeks— The text is the first verse of the 14th. Chapter of John, and there is a note that to derive any useful fruit from the Sermon, it is indispensably necessary, before perusing it, to read the 14th. 15th. and 16th. chapters of John. It is less impressive than some other Discourses of the same collection— The Dutch reformed Churches, and those of the French Protestants, keep the festivals of Christmas and Easter, and this volume is occasional; containing a Sermon delivered upon each of the days having reference to the Birth, Death or Resurrection of Christ— This was all the reading that I could accomplish this day, and with the minutes of Diary for yesterday and this day, absorbed my whole time— I heard my Granddaughter read twice, and in the evening wade through 30 pages of Professor Dew’s Review of the Debate, on the project for Slave emancipation. It is a monument of the intellectual perversion produced by the existence of Slavery in a free community— To the mind of Mr Dew, Slavery is the source of all Virtue in the heart of the Master.— His argument against the practicability, of abolishing Slavery by means of Colonization, appears to me conclusive, nor do I believe that emancipation is the object of the Colonization Society, though it may be the daydream of some of its members. Mr Dews argument that the danger of Insurrection among the Slaves diminished in proportion as their relative numbers increase over those of the white masters is an ingenious paradox in which I have no faith.
14. V. Monday.

I have been vainly diverted from one inconsiderate occupation to another, and spent much of the day in copying and completing a Proem— My projected Address to the People slumbers— I planted a row of Apples and seeds, Pear Cores Walnuts Plum-stones and [symbols] between the young elms at the bottom of the Nursery; and two short ones above the central cross alley Eastward, where I introduced some better soil from the garden— My Son Charles came out from Boston, and dined with us— He says that a fifth Candidate for the Office of Governor of the Commonwealth has been nominated in the person of Samuel C. Allen by a meeting of the working men. This makes it probable that there will be no election by the People— Charles is chairman of a Committee of the Anti-masonic Convention to prepare a memorial to the Legislature praying them to institute an examination into the nature of the Masonic Institution, in
this Commonwealth— Mr Bailey had mentioned this to me, and Charles said he wished to consult me with regard to the composition of the Memorial— He returned about Sunset to Boston. Louisa C Smith came to spend a fortnight with my wife before our departure for Washington— She has been passing the Summer at Mrs. T. B. Adams’s— I read further in Professor Dew’s review of the Slavery debate in the Legislature of Virginia— This pamphlet deserves grave meditation, and has in it the seeds of much profitable Instruction. Slavery is in all probability the wedge which will ultimately split up this Union. It is the source of all the disaffection to it, in both parts of the Country— A disaffection deeply pervading Mr Dew’s pamphlet— With my multifarious occupations my Correspondence and Diary are running again into arrears, and the biography of my father is totally suspended— The Summer is irretrievably gone.
15. III.45. Tuesday

Another almost sleepless night. Mr Beale was here this Morning, with a Subscription paper in Shares for an Aqueduct to bring water from a Spring in Dorchester to the Neponset Bridge Toll-house— He persuaded me to take one share of it, somewhat against my inclination— He brought also a plan for a Stone School house, to be built according to the directions of my father’s donations to the Town, and the cost of which will not exceed 4000 dollars— Fervently do I wish that I could take upon myself that expense; but it is utterly beyond my means; with the burdens which bear me down, and from which I despair of obtaining relief. I went with my wife to Boston— Paid a visit to William Sturgis but he was not at home. Called upon Mr Lord to enquire about the application from the State of Ohio, for a thousand copies of the Poem of Dermot MacMorrogh— He has agreed with a Printer and Bookseller at Cincinnati, who is to print an Edition of 1000 copies in duodecimo, for which he allows Lord a small compensation, who said he would divide it with me— I proposed to him to give in this 3d. Edition 25 or 30 new Stanzas, and read to him the Proem which consists of 12. He thought they would quicken the Sale of the new Edition, and said he would write to the contractor immediately to stop the Press, and make a new arrangement with him. I gave him the Proem asking him to shew it to Mr Pierpont, and take his opinion of it— He told me Pishey Thompson had failed at Washington. At Charles’s Office I saw William Plumer junr and Alexander Townsend who is in high excitement about the election; and would be wiser if he was cooler. We dined with Charles, who gave me his own candid opinion of Dermot MacMorrogh. That it excites no interest— The freedom with which he expresses this opinion, deserves my respect and is a pledge of the goodness of his heart as well as of the firmness of his temper and of the sincerity of his filial affection— We came home at the dusk of Evening.
16. IV:20. Wednesday.

Mrs Harris is an old woman residing at Stoughton; widow of a Revolutionary Soldier named Oliver Harris, who enjoyed a Pension for a year and a half before he died; but she thinks he was wronged and was entitled to it for a longer time than he received it. General Dearborn presented a Petition for her at the last Session of Congress, and it was referred to a Committee; I suppose the widow’s Committee; but they did not report. She
wished me to see to its being revived, which I promised to do. She left with me two Papers, and told me a long Story which it will be impossible for me to retain in my Memory. But she promised that either General Dearborn, or squire Tolman should write me a statement of facts in the case.— Alpheus Spear sent his Son, with his last Quarter’s Rent. I planted several short rows of Apple-seeds, Pear-Cores, Nuts and Cherries in the Nursery and found that the Apple of the central tree just now ripe is an excellent fruit— I was occupied great part of the day, in copying Stanza’s for the third Edition of Dermot MacMorrogh, in inconsiderate disregard of the wise and honest admonition of my Son. I wrote also a short Letter to Samuel N. Sweet, at Adams, Jefferson County, New-York— The autumnal rains have commenced and there is a prospect that the Springs will be replenished— I wasted part of the Evening in Meditation upon the signs of the Zodiac in the fourth book of the Astronomics of Manilius.

div.p: 17. IV.30. Thursday.

Showery Night and Morning. I was all the day till near Sunset absorbed in occupation— Walked over, up the hill, as night was coming on, to view the grain sown by Solomon Thayer, the 18th. of last Month— It is up, but looks rather thin and unpromising. I spent half an hour in the garden, which at this Season, ceases altogether to be inviting— I am copying the Stanza’s on the Astrology of the Zodiac for a revised Edition of Dermot MacMorrogh. I received a Letter from Lord, with one to him from Mr Pierpont, who objects to the term Bard as applied to Cicero, how that word was of all others the one, which I could not possibly consent to strike out, and Mr Pierpont’s Letter was otherwise not very encouraging to the publication of the Proem— I shewed it to my wife who objected to two of the Stanzas—precisely those which Lord thought the best of the whole— I immediately determined not to publish the Proem now— I merely altered one Stanza, supplied that which was in the first and second Edition left in blank, and wrote to Lord to direct the Contractor at Cincinnati to print from the second Edition, with these two alterations. I feel easier after this determination— Scarcely any man in this Country who has figured in public life, has ever ventured in to the field of general Literature—None successfully— I have attempted it, in the Letters from Silesia, in the Lectures upon Rhetoric and Oratory; in occasional fugitive pieces in verse—original and translated, and finally in this Poem of Dermot MacMorrogh which is original and at once a work of History, Imagination and Poetry— It has come to a third Edition, and will now be forgotten; as will be all my other writings in prose and verse— Like the rest of American Poetry, it resembles the juice of American grapes— It has not in ripening, the property of acquiring alcohol enough to keep it in preservation— I have pushed my experiment on the public temper far enough.— In the Evening I read to the Ladies in an Edinburgh Review of 1823 the Article upon the Memoirs of Lord Waldegrave, and of Lord Orford, relating to the Court History of the latter part of the reign of George the second— I took up again the fourth Book of Manilius and wasted some time upon it— I deeply regret that I have but a fortnight left before I am to depart for Washington.
18. IV.15 Friday

My wife went to Boston this morning with Louisa C. Smith— They returned home to dine. Our Grand-child Mary Louisa passed the day at Mrs T. B. Adams’s— Mr and Mrs Webster paid us a morning visit; we regretted that my wife was not at home to receive the Lady— They were going to Marshfield, but only for two or three days. I was employed in copying Stanzas upon Judicial Astrology and the Zodiac, till by the Mail I received a Letter from Governor Lincoln of nine pages, in answer to one from me, asking him whether he had received from me in April 1832 a Letter recommendatory of John B. Davis— There is a sore and wounded Spirit pervading the whole Letter, for which I can account only by the belief that his temper has been soured by the whispers of the same Slanderer, who secretly stimulated him against me two years ago. He then acknowledged to me the fact, but declined giving me the name of the informer— This man or another like him must have been at work with the Governor again. I thought it best to postpone replying to the parts of his Letter relating to Masonry, Anti-Masonry, my consistency and the purity of his Administration from Masonic influence, until after the issue of the pending Election— Here is another friend converted into a bitter and inveterate enemy by the influence of Masonry. I replied however, immediately to the other part of his Letter, and took my reply to the Post-Office, enclosing it to my Son Charles to be copied at Boston— In further pursuit of this controversy, I have need of the restraining Genius of Socrates— Advice what to suppress— I planted in the Garden, between two Peach Trees, a row of split Office Apples. Finished reading to the Ladies in the Evening the Article in the Edinburgh Review upon Waldegrave’s and Orford’s Memoirs.
19. V. Saturday.

William Spear was here this morning, with the advertisement for the sale of the wood remaining on the Borland lot. The Sale to be on the first of November. The Auctioneer Harvey Field— He said there was some question about one of the bounds, and I gave him the plan of Survey made by M. Withington in 1826. Mr Daniel Frost, an Agent for the Norfolk County Temperance Society, brought me a recommendatory Letter from the Revd. Joseph Richardson of Hingham— Mr Frost is a lawyer, but proposes to deliver a Lecture on Temperance to-morrow Evening in this Town— He wishes also to institute a new Temperance Society— There is one already—but his object is to get up another in connection with the general association, and he intimated a wish that I would take a lead in forming it— I declined, from an unwillingness to shackle myself with obligations to controul my individual family and domestic arrangements, from an apprehension that the Temperance Societies, in their well intended zeal, are already manifesting a tendency to encroach upon personal freedom; and from an opinion that the cause itself is so well sustained by others, and so favoured by public approbation and applause, that it needs not the aid of any special exertion of mine, beyond that of my own example— I mentioned to him the Lecture of Mr L. M. Sargent in which he urged with great earnestness the necessity of a pledge of total abstinence from wine as well as from ardent Spirits, which I told him I was not prepared from the established habits of my life to give, and which would be in direct contradiction to the advice of Dr Holbrook my Physician; himself a temperate man; and in whose experience, skill and judgment I had great confidence.
My Son Charles came out from Boston, and dined with us, and returned to Boston, in the Evening. I gave him my certificate for 80 Shares of the Massachusetts Fire and Marine Insurance Company; and a power of Attorney to sell them— Read in the Evening, the Edinburgh Review of George Canning’s dinner-table Speeches at Liverpool in 1822— I planted this day a row of 6 whole central Nursery Apples, along the fence nearly opposite to the tree itself, with walnuts and [symbols] and a row of other apples in a patch below— The frost has killed all my vines.
20. IV.30 Sunday.

The preacher this day was a young man by the name of Burton; his morning text was from 2. Corinthians 4.17 [“]For our light affliction, which is but for a moment, worketh for us a far more exceeding, and eternal weight of glory.” On temporary afflictions— In the afternoon it was upon Anger—from Proverbs 16.32. He that is slow to Anger is better than the mighty; and he that ruleth his Spirit, than he that taketh a city— They were both edifying discourses—particularly the latter, but very indifferently delivered— Our unitarian preachers are almost universally cold and drawling in their elocution— Their Sermons are disquisitions upon abstract points of morals, and they are so dependent upon their Parish that they dare not set before them their real vices and corruptions— There was rather more boldness in Mr Burton’s addresses to his hearers than is usual— I read the fourth Sermon of the 5th. Volume of Saurin, upon the Sacerdotal prayer of Jesus Christ— Preached on one of the Sundays of the Passion—that is, of Lent— The text is the whole 17th. chapter of John, and it is a sequel to the preceding Sermon, which was upon the 14th. 15th. and 16th. Chapters. Saurin always reasons upon the mysteries of his doctrines as if he did not himself believe his own argument— He always entangles himself with objections, which he feebly attempts, and is unable to refute— In this Sermon he runs foul of the unity of Jesus Christ, with God the father— He maintains that Jesus Christ is one, with the father as God—and also as Mediator between God and Man— He says that this unity of Christ, as Mediator, with God, has its degrees—(degrees of unity!) and that as Mediator, Christ was never in error, but that he did not always know the whole truth— The whole of this Sermon may be called Gallimatius. Well may he apostrophise the mysteries of Redemption, and exclaim how far they are above our expressions and our thoughts!— It rained, or rather sprinkled the whole day, and I rode home from Meeting. Morning and Afternoon— The auditories were very thin. Notice was given after the morning service, that Mr Frost would deliver his Lecture on Temperance, at the Episcopal Church at half past six O’Clock this Evening— I intended to have gone to it, but it rained heavily in the Evening and I concluded not to go. I resumed my Diary in this book, and wrote a long Letter to Dr Waterhouse.
21. IV.30. Monday—

There was a sprinkling rain continued through the whole day—which confined me to the house; excepting about a half an hour after dinner, when I planted in my Nursery 5. Dwarf Apples whole, in a row opposite the central Apple-tree along the Eastern fence. I was then obliged to retreat within the house again— I was very steadily occupied the whole day and Evening. My Grand-Child Mary-Louisa has been these two days unwell, and her reading Lessons have been abridged— She yesterday finished reading the Child’s own Book, and I gave her this Morning the Fables for the Nursery— But upon trial I found she was not sufficiently advanced for reading them, and I put her into the blue Spelling-Book— I began and wrote three pages
of a Letter to Governor Lincoln, in reply to his Letter of nine pages to me— The more I reflect upon that Letter the more unfair, bitter and rancorous it appears to me— He imputes to my Anti-masonic publications the falling off of his Supporters, and the consequent necessity to him of declining a Re-election— I believe him to be mistaken— My Letters have given strength to the argument of the Anti Masonic Cause, but they have roused and stimulated all the energies of all my personal Adversaries, against the Cause espoused by me— All personal opposition to me redounds to the benefit of Masonry— This will be the only cement to keep the National Republican party together— They would now go to pieces but for the rallying point of opposition to me— It is two years since I published the Letters on the Masonic controversy, with which I began, and one since the publication of those upon the Entered Apprentice’s Oath— In that time the numbers of the Anti Masonic party do not appear to have increased in this Commonwealth at all— They have apparently diminished, in New-York and Pennsylvania— They are wavering in Rhode-Island, and although they have atchieved a signal triumph in Vermont their power is precarious, and a more complete union between the two political parties, would yet prostrate anti-masonry— This controversy seems destined to destroy the comforts and tranquility of my last days, and to bring my life to close in hopeless conflict with the world.
22. IV:15. Tuesday

A Night and third day of steady though very moderate rain— Rather a continual sprinkling— It confined me all day to the house, except a visit of about ten minutes to the Nursery towards Evening; from which I was obliged to retreat again to the house. Our Grand-child Mary-Louisa is yet unwell. Mr Clay came out from Boston this Morning and paid me a visit, with Messrs. Lawrence Gorham and Appleton— Mr Clay arrived in Boston yesterday— He is making a tour, and since he reached the Atlantic border, has been received at Baltimore—Philadelphia—New-York—Providence and Boston, with great demonstrations of respect— This fashion of peddling for popularity by travelling round the Country; gathering crowds together, hawking for public dinners, and spouting empty Speeches, is growing into high fashion. It was formerly confined to the Presidents, but De Witt Clinton made some unsuccessful experiments of it— Mr Clay has mounted that hobby often, and rides him very hard. President Jackson made an awkward figure at it last Summer. Having upon one of his excursions got his nose pulled; and being in his Processions here très pressé, with a Dysentery. Mr Clay had two deputations sent to him from Boston, at Providence— One, of the tough Seignors to invite him to a Public Dinner; and one of the tender Juveniles to escort him into the City. He entered Boston yesterday in a procession, and was paraded round the Streets in the midst of all the Rain— He appears to be in good health, though he said he was not so— He said he had seen Mr and Mrs Rush at Philadelphia, and that they were well— That Mr Rush had sent a copy of his Book to President Jackson, and upon his returning a civil answer, had in his reply declared his approbation of the measure of removing the public deposits from the Bank of the US— I was surprized at this; but Mr Clay said Mr Biddle told him that Mr Rush had avowed the fact to him— Mr Clay said there was an answer by the Directors of the Bank, to the President’s
paper, read to the Cabinet—it was in the Press and would be published in a few days— Mr Lawrence left with me a note of invitation, for my wife and me from him and Mrs Lawrence to a party this Evening at their house— I told Mr Lawrence that we could not come— An answer declining was sent by the Mail— I was drudgingly engaged the day and Evening upon a reply to Governor Lincoln’s strange Letter.
23. V:15. Wednesday.

Fine weather. We had intended to go into Boston this Morning to return our visits, but the child Mary Louisa, was taken ill in the Night and continued so much indisposed this Morning that my wife concluded not to leave home, but to postpone the return of our visits till to-morrow— My Son Charles came out from Boston this afternoon, and spent a couple of hours with us, and returned home in the evening— We received a card of invitation from the late Lieutt. Governor Winthrop, and his daughter, to dinner to-morrow, to meet Mr and Mrs Clay, which we declined, on account of the recent death of Thomas J. Hellen. I planted in the Nursery a row or two of Apples, Pear Cores, Walnuts, grape-seeds and Peach Stones— I now scatter these about, in the hope that some of them will come up next Spring and Summer. But my time, and thoughts and feelings are so much engrossed by this ridiculous Letter from Governor Lincoln, that I have no moment left for preparation to depart, although we intend going for Washington the next week— I gave Charles two sheets of it to be copied— I began it with the intention of not sending it until after the issue of the pending Election, but it may perhaps be sent sooner.
24. V:15 Thursday

I sat writing so late last Night that on going to bed I could not sleep and it was between one and two this Morning before I fell into a Slumber. I went to Boston this Morning with my wife and Mrs Angier whom we took up at her Mother’s—Mrs T. B. Adams’s— We returned the visits of Mr and Mrs Webster, leaving Cards—Mr Webster being at his Office and Mrs Webster not very well— We left cards also at the Tremont house, for Mr and Mrs Clay, who were not there— I was sometime at Charles’s Office, and called three times at Mr Lord’s before I found him— I had determined to make no other alteration in the third Edition of Dermot MacMorrogh, than to fill up the Stanzas which had been left in blank, and to alter one other— Mr Lord settled with me for the three Editions, and I directed him not to publish any more, without the additions— I told him I would prepare a fourth Edition, to contain the Proem—an Introduction of twenty-three new Stanza to the third Canto, and eight or ten other Stanza’s interspers’d in different parts of the Poem— He said he had already given directions to the person who undertakes to print the Edition at Cincinnati— I left Cards for Mrs Adams and myself at Mr Abbott Lawrence’s, and at the Tremont house for Mr B. Gorham— Called at Bond’s, but he wished to keep my Chronometer a few days longer, and I left it still with him— I called at Charles’s House and saw his wife and children— He said something about having his Son baptized at Quincy, but I advised him to have that ceremony performed, at Mr Frothingham’s church in Boston, where he himself and his first child were christened. We returned home to Quincy to dine— Mrs Angier dined with us and returned home to her mother’s towards Evening— From dinnertime till ten at Night I was constantly occupied in writing; not to my satisfaction— My wife was quite ill this Evening.
25. III.45. Friday.

The pressure upon my time is almost more than I can bear, and the subjects discussed in my Letter to Governor Lincoln spread before me till I know not where it will end— The more I write, the more of trouble I anticipate, and yet a sense of indispensable duty urges me on— I subject myself to so much toil, and so much enmity, with so very little apparent fruit, that I sometimes ask myself, whether I do not mistake my own motives.— The best actions of my Life make me nothing but Enemies. Mr Whitney our Minister paid me a morning visit to take leave— Francis Williams the Collector came, and I paid him the Balance of my tax-bill for the present year. Mr Beman a Student in Theology, brought me a Letter from Mr Woodbridge Editor of a Periodical publication called the Annals of Education, which is sinking for want of Patronage— The third Volume is to close with the present year— I took a set from the beginning and paid the Subscription till the end of the year 1834.— I walked towards Evening to Mrs T. B. Adams’s and delivered her a Letter from her Son Isaac Hull, a Cadet at West-Point. Mr Beale called and paid us an Evening visit.— With Walter Foss and John Kirk, I took up an Horse Chesnut, two Elms, and three Chesnut Oaks, in the Summerhouse Cellar, and set them out in the enclosure Eastward of my house— I also planted the fourth and last row of Apples and Seeds, Pear Cores, and Walnuts, at the bottom of the Nursery. The child Mary Louisa, is so unwell that Dr Woodward attends her.
26. IV. Saturday

My wife went into Boston this morning, and returned to dine. Mrs Isaac Brooks and Miss Anna Thaxter were here, and brought me a Letter from the Revd. Charles Brooks of Hingham requesting a Letter of introduction to General La Fayette— Mr Brooks is going to spend a year in Europe for the improvement of his health. He has obtained permission for that purpose from his Parish, and proposes to go next Tuesday from Boston to New-York, there to embark for Havre— My Son Charles came from Boston and dined with us, and returned this Evening home. He has made his arrangements for having his Son baptized to-morrow, and invited his Mother, me, and Louisa C. Smith to go in, be present at the Ceremony and dine with him— I had two or three interruptions yesterday which prevented me from finishing the transplantation of my trees, and this day I was prevented entirely from resuming it— I wrote upon my Letter to Governor Lincoln, but the subject enlarges as I proceed— Though I rise at four in the morning, and write till ten at Night, my progress is exceedingly slow and I am very diffuse for want of method— But my daily minutes of the chapters of the Bible which I read: my Diary, and the Letters I am occasionally obliged to answer absorb so large a portion of my time that they break in upon the continuity of my argument continually— Hence I am seldom able to write any thing of it after breakfast— This Evening I wrote a Letter of Introduction for Mr Charles Brooks to General La Fayette, to whom I send copies of my 4th. of July Oration at Quincy, and my Eulogy upon Mr Monroe of 25 August 1831— I wrote also a Letter to my Son Charles, to deliver to him, with my father’s Seal, and took a copy of the Letter— The child Mary Louisa was very sick, and had some fever— Dr Holbrook attended her. My teaching her to read is of course totally suspended.
27. III:45 Sunday.

I went into Boston this Morning, with Mrs Adams and Louisa C. Smith—we stop’d and left her at Mr James H Foster’s, and went on to my Son Charles’s house N. 3. Hancock Avenue— We thence went to the first Church in Summer Street, where my Grandson was baptized by Mr Frothingham by the name of John Quincy, and may it please almighty God, that the child may live and grow up with his blessing and make his name respectable and useful in his own person— Dr Stevenson had a daughter baptized at the same time. Charles and his wife held their child during the ceremony, and Charles presented him at the baptismal font. Mr Frothingham afterwards preached from 1. Corinthians 1.27 “But God hath chosen the foolish things of the world, to confound the wise; and God hath chosen the weak things of the world, to confound the things which are mighty”—one of the most excellent Sermons that I ever heard— The theme is rich, and it was treated with great power— We all dined with Charles— I gave him my father’s Seal at arms, and the Letter I had written to him last Evening— I left with him also the Letter to General La Fayette, with the copies of my two Discourses, to be given to Mr Charles Brooks— Charles showed me five Volumes of my fathers and mothers Manuscript Letters which he has had bound— After dinner Charles took home to Medford, Mrs Reed, the Nurse of his Son, from his birth, but who now leaves him. Mr Degrand came after dinner and spent an hour with me— He is still friendly to me; and flatters himself that a portion of the National Republican party will cast their votes for me. In this he is certainly mistaken— Single individuals using no influence in Elections beyond themselves may vote for me; but the parties are so organized and disciplined that the National Republicans may probably carry their whole ticket— The excess of zeal inspired by the single motive of opposition to me, will more than balance any defection from the National Republican ranks in my favour— At half past three we left Charles’s House, and returned to Quincy—reaching home before five— Price Greenleaf was here in the Evening, and asked me to lend him Michaux’s Silva America, for the winter, which I readily promised— I began to read but could not finish the 5th. Sermon of Saurin’s 5th. Volume, on the Passion.— I had more comfort, upon retiring to bed with my Prayers and my hopes this Evening, than I have had for some years— May they be realized!
28 IV. Monday

I rose at 4 in the morning, and wrote till ten at Night, but this Letter to Governor Lincoln, reminds me of the lines in Goldsmith’s hermit— Where wilds immeasurably spread seem lengthening as I go— It will be impossible for me to finish it as I would wish before my departure for Washington; nor there where I shall want many books and pamphlets to which I must resort— I have also been compelled to write with so much precipitation that there will be many weak points in it of which advantage will be taken— I hope I shall not suffer it to go without a thorough revisal, and severe self-criticism— It takes me almost entirely from my Garden and Nursery, so that I shall not have time for transplanting my trees— I did merely transplant a seedling Pear tree, from Pot N. 3. to the Garden, and planted in the Pot, filled with fresh Earth one whole dwarf Apple and 4 [symbols] Deacon Adams was here this morning, and this afternoon Mr. I P Davis, and Alexander Townsend came out from Boston and paid me a visit. Davis had a book recently published in England, by a Traveller in the United States named Foot, in which there are engravings of the old man of the Mountain, of Ethan Crawford’s
house—and of the Notch of the White Mountains— The profile is not well executed—the others are sufficiently well done— Davis has been to Washington, since we were in New-Hampshire— Townsend told me that in some of the Philadelphia papers, my Fable of the Plague in the forest published in the Token of 1834. was attacked as a Plagiarism from Florian—and that the extracts from Florian were given the pretended Plagiarisms; but there was no similarity, and far less of identity, between the passages quoted and those pretended to be borrowed from them— I said that the charge of stealing from Florian was ridiculous—there was not a line of his in my fable; which was taken from La Fontaines Animaux Malades de la Peste—not as a Plagiarism; but as La Fontaine himself had taken from Phaedrus, from AEsop, and from every fabulist who had written before him— La Harpe expressly says that La Fontaine invented nothing, and it is affirmed that not one of his whole collection of Fables is original— I have made free with him as he made free with others— Davis said that the same view of it was taken by a writer who defended me in the New-York Evening Post, a paper where he should not have expected it— My fable is told in my own way;—borrowing from La Fontaine what I could well adapt to the English Language; but varying the details at my pleasure— Lewis Bass and William Field were here this Evening, and settled with me for their Rents.
29. IV. Tuesday

Mrs Adams went into Boston this morning, and returned home to dine— Elizabeth C Adams dined with us— I had a succession of visitors the whole day long, which did in no wise advance the progress of my Letter to Governor Lincoln— A Mr Procter came here from Boston and gave me a long and wearisome account of a claim upon the Government of the United States, of indemnity for certain English goods. Broadcloths, seized by him as a Custom-house Officer at Castine during the late War; but which were restored by order of the Government to their owners— He says he was at an expense of more than eight thousand dollars, in those Seizures, and in the prosecutions which succeeded them, which have never been paid. He thinks the Government, ought fully to indemnify him. He dwelt in his narrative upon so many minute and uninteresting details that it became almost insupportable to me—luckily Solomon Thayer came in and interrupted him— I advised him to prepare a Petition to Congress; and promised if he would send it to me, to present it to the House of Representatives— I had sent word to Mr Thayer that I wished to see him. He came, and I read to him the Letter from the Secretary of War, and the Letter from J. L. Edwards to him containing their objections to the increase of Mr Thayer’s pension— He explained the principal one to my Satisfaction— I desired him to make the same Statement in writing—and promised to take it on with me to Washington and discuss the matter with the Secretary of War— Dr Zacheus Bartlett was next here, and gave me two affidavits in the support of claims to Pensioners named Burges, brothers belonging to Plymouth—he named a third, which I took down in a pencil mark— Mr Bartlett said Something upon Politics, but not much. After him came a Mr Gerard Battles, from Scituate, accompanied by a neighbour of his, a Mr Stodder— Battles thinks he has a claim to be paid for certain sails of a boat belonging to him, which were taken from him, in the year 1776, for Soldiers tents. He admits that he was paid for them at the time: but it was in paper money which
was good for nothing, and he thinks he ought to be paid for his Sails again— Upon further conversation I found that his Sails had been taken under the authority of the Provincial Government, and told him he must petition the General Court of the Commonwealth. Battles was himself a Soldier during the Revolutionary War, and has a Pension of 80 dollars a year—but he says he was obliged to pay 12 dollars for his papers to procure it. I had an afternoon visit from Mr B. F. Hallett, and Mr Gassett who took tea with us. Mr Hallett gave me his Report of the trial of E. K. Avery; and that of the trial of E. Clough for Embracery— I finished reading the second Volume of C. Thomson’s Translation of the Septuagint Bible, and of the Book of Psalms—where I shall pause for the present—to proceed in the reading of the next volume, on my return here next Spring.— This Translation is upon the whole far inferior to the common English Bible—and in no part of it more than the Book of Psalms— My Diary lingers.
30. IV. Wednesday

We have a succession of frosty Nights and cold days. My Garden and Nursery are repulsive, and I have less and less time for working in them— I must again go away without transplanting most of my trees— I resumed the reading of the common Bible with the Book of Job, but wrote no minutes— Ebenezer Adams was here, and I settled with him an account for six Cords of wood— Settled also several other Bills— Solomon Thayer was here and gave me a paper containing a new statement in support of his claim for an increase of Pension— After dinner I went with Kirk into Boston, and got from my Son Charles money to make up 200 dollars for my wife who proposes to depart to-morrow for Washington— I was about an hour at Charles’s house, and then returned home—which I reached before seven— Evening employed in writing with much difficulty— Charles told me that my Fable of the Plague in the forest was published in the National Intelligencer, with a remark that some persons had perceived in it a political bearing, which they, were unable to understand— I thought of Swift’s Key to the Lock, and of old Captain Brown’s answer to me on board the Frigate Alliance in 1779. Upon my asking him whether any such People as those mentioned in Gulliver’s Travels existed in any part of the world—he said yes—they were all to be found in the Isle of Man— My Fable has brought the Editor of the Token into trouble— The book has been annually published, several years in succession, and has been regularly puffed and gone into oblivion. This year it has been furiously attacked, and as faintly and insidiously defended— The Baltimore Patriot asks if it is the Plague in the Forest that has given the fever to the Boston Editors— They have not named the Fable, but assailed the whole book of which it constitutes about four pages. This is one of the imps the hopeful progeny of the union of free-masonry, with Essex-Juntoism, and Hartford Convention federalism.
31. IV:15. Thursday

Sharp frost last Night, and almost winter’s cold though fair this day. At nine this morning my wife, with her maid Margaret, our Grand-child Mary Louisa and John Kirk with the Carriage and horses departed for Washington— She proposes to go if possible this Night to Providence,
and to embark to morrow in the Steamer President for New-York— I was occupied all the morning, most of the afternoon and great part of the Evening in writing. I planted in my Nursery a Row of whole Saint Germain Pears, down along the side of the Eastern fence.— The leaves of the Peach trees and most of the others are killed by the frost— I took off one of the stems of the Button-wood tree growing from a twig which I stuck down in the Nursery in Novr 1830, and set it out in the Garden— About Sunset I walked to the small Bridge beyond Coll Quincy’s gate for exercise; it was pinching cold. Mr William Spear was here this Morning, and returned me my plan of the Borland Wood-lot— The Sale of the Wood is to be made to-morrow.

Day. Never in my life did I experience so rapid a march of Time, as since my return from the excursion to the White Mountains of New-Hampshire— My Sons John and Charles with their families have returned John to Washington and Charles to Boston— My wife is this day gone, and I myself am to follow her next week— My health though drooping has to superficial appearance improved— I rise generally between four and five— Make my fire— Have this Month read five Psalms every Morning, and made minutes of them. Breakfast from 8 to 9. read newspapers, write, and receive visitors till 12 or 1. Spend an hour or two in my garden and Nursery— Dine from two to three— Write or read in my Study till Sunset. Walk half an hour— Meet my family at tea, and write about two hours of the Evening. My correspondence is in arrears— For the last fortnight I have been busied in writing an answer of 40 pages to a Letter of nine from Governor Lincoln and I have not yet finished— I had previously commenced writing an Address to the People of the Commonwealth which I have suspended and shall probably not resume.
